SUMMARY:  On April 11, 2016, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst for Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present was CC Song, Regulatory Analyst for MCE. MCE requested clarity on the procedural next steps for this proceeding. MCE stated the need for the Commission to create a tracking and reporting process for voluntarily adopted energy storage devices that receive Self-Generation Incentive Program funds within Community Choice Aggregation (CCA) service areas. MCE also requested the Commission to provide guidance in Track 2 of the proceeding on the storage procurement targets of emerging CCAs.

Description: [Joint;] SUMMARY:  On January 12, 2016, Ms. Sue Mara, Principal with RTOAdvisors, L.L.C., and consultant to The Alliance for Retail Energy Markets1 (AReM) and Direct Access Customer Coalition (DACC), met with Sepideh Khosrowjah, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, in San Francisco.  Greg Bass, Director, Noble Americas Energy Solutions LLC, and Cynthia Clark, Associate Wholesale Electricity Program Manager, University of California, Office of the President, attended the meeting by telephone. Mara, Bass and Clark explained that AReM and DACC strongly objected to the December 15, 2015 proposed decision's (PD) determination that the investor-owned utilities (IOUs) would be permitted to count all of the energy storage projects funded partially through the Self-Generation Incentive Program. Mara, Bass and Clark also discussed the PD's determination that the load-serving entity of the customers installing energy storage projects should retain the storage credits.  Mara, Bass and Clark stated AReM and DACC have proposed that the customer that invested in the energy storage project be able to assign the energy storage procurement "credit" to the LSE as they choose.  Mara discussed the PD's determinations regarding the Power Charge Indifference Amount (PCIA). Mara explained that all PCIA policy issues should be addressed uniformly in Track 2 in this rulemaking.  Mara explained that the PD erred in stating that the Commission would determine the PCIA cost recovery period for the IOUs' 2014 energy storage solicitations in the separate proceedings.  Mara requested that the PD be revised.

for Party Status
Reply Comments on the Proposed Decision

SUMMARY: On January 6, 2016, Sue Mara, Principal with RTOAdvisors, L.L.C., and consultant to The Alliance for Retail Energy Markets (AReM), met with Scott Murtishaw, advisor to Cmmr. Picker, and?Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings in San Francisco.  Greg Bass, Director, Noble Americas Energy Solutions LLC., attended the meetings by telephone.  Mara and Bass explained that AReM and direct access customers (DAC) strongly objected to the Proposed Decision's (PD) determination that the investor-owned utilities (IOUs) would be permitted to count all of the energy storage projects funded partially through the Self-Generation Incentive Program.  Mara and Bass discussed the PD's determination that the load-serving entity of the customers installing energy storage projects should retain the storage credits.  Mara and Bass stated that AReM and the DAC Coalition have proposed that the customer that invested in the energy storage project be able to assign the energy storage procurement "credit" to the LSE. Mara and Bass discussed the PD's determination regarding the Power Charge Indifference Amount (PCIA), and explained that all PCIA policy issues should be addressed uniformly in Track 2 in this rulemaking. Mara explained that the PD erred in stating that the Commission would determine the PCIA cost recovery period for the IOUs' 2014 energy storage solicitations in the separate proceedings addressing the IOUs' applications.  Mara requested that the PD be revised to correct that error.

Filed By: Alliance for Retail Energy Markets,Direct Access Customer Coalition,Marin Clean Energy,City of Lancaster,Shell Energy North America (US), L.P.
Description: Reply Comments on the Proposed Decision

SUMMARY:  On January 4, 2016, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst for Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present was CC Song, Regulatory Analyst for MCE.  MCE representatives voiced concerns regarding the language within the Proposed Decision which would continue to limit SGIP-funded ES deployment to only being countable towards the Investor-Owned Utilities' (IOUs) ES procurement targets. MCE expressed its concern that the continued prohibition of Community Choice Aggregator's (CCAs) abilities to count SGIP-funded ES deployment towards their procurement targets, would likely lead to stagnation in the development of customer-side ES market segment. MCE reminded the Commission of MCE's collaboration with the College of Marin and Tesla Motors Inc. to install on-site ES. MCE representatives stated this resource will be located on the premises of a MCE customer within MCE's service territory, yet MCE is not presently able to claim credit for the development of this resource towards its ES procurement target, per Decision 13-10-040. MCE staff questioned whether there may still be a middle-ground solution that would allow both IOUs and CCAs to count of SGIP-funded ES resources towards their procurement targets.

Assigned Commissioner and Assigned Administrative Law Judge's Scoping Memo and Ruling seeking comments.  Rulemaking 15-03-011 is categorized as quasi-legislative. Evidentiary hearings are not needed at this time. A final resolution on the need for hearing will be made at a later date. The scope of and the schedule for Track 2 of this proceeding are as set forth. This proceeding will conclude within 24 months from the date of the June 12, 2015 Scoping Memo. Parties are requested to file and serve comments on the questions set forth herein; opening and reply comments shall be filed and served on January 29, 2016 and February 12, 2016, respectively.  Commissioner Carla J. Peterman is the designated presiding officer in this proceeding.

California Indpendent System Operator Corporation noticed written ex parte communications to President Picker, Commissioner Florio, Commissioner Sandoval, Commissioner Peterman, and Commissioner Randolph on July 21, 2015.

SUMMARY:  On July 21, 2015, Steve Berberich, Chief Executive Officer and President of the California Independent System Operator Corporation (CAISO), sent a letter to all five Commissioners and their respective Chiefs of Staff and Energy Advisors. Although the letteraddressed R.13-12-010, the CAISO files the instant notice because the Scoping Memo in this proceeding specifically seeks to evaluate "whether new information and/or evolving circumstances exist such that the Commission should revisit previously excluded energy storage technologies such as vehicle-grid integration and pumped hydro storage."  A copy of the letter is attached to the notice.
